title: 109_hr3988
content:
The Act titled "Gulf Coast Small Business Recovery Act" prioritizes small businesses in procurement related to Hurricane Katrina and Hurricane Rita. The "Gulf Coast Small Business Recovery Act" gives priority to businesses in Gulf hurricane disaster-affected areas for procurement related to Hurricane Katrina and Rita. The "Gulf Coast Small Business Recovery Act" mandates that a certain percentage of procurement contracts related to Hurricane Katrina and Rita must be awarded to small businesses in Gulf hurricane disaster-affected areas. The "Gulf Coast Small Business Recovery Act" requires a percentage of procurement contracts related to Hurricane Katrina and Rita to be awarded to small businesses in Gulf hurricane disaster-affected areas. Federal departments must provide opportunities for small businesses and ensure compliance with subcontracting goals under the Small Business Act. The head of a Federal department or agency must ensure that contracts comply with subcontracting goals for small businesses under the Small Business Act and Federal Acquisition Regulations. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration must submit a report to Congress within 2 years, detailing opportunities for small businesses. This subsection will terminate at a specified time. The Administration must report to Congress on opportunities for small businesses under this subsection. The subsection will end one day after all Federal Disaster Declaration notices for Gulf hurricane disaster-affected areas are lifted. Gulf hurricane disaster-affected small businesses are treated as HUBZone businesses under the Small Business Act during the period of a Federal Disaster Declaration for the county where the business is located as of August 28, 2005. Prohibition on permanent relocation of federal facilities from Gulf hurricane disaster-affected areas. Prohibition on permanent relocation of federal facilities from Gulf hurricane disaster-affected areas. This provision prohibits any federal facility from being permanently moved from a Gulf hurricane disaster-affected area to a location outside that area. The restriction expires after two years from the enactment of this Act. Additionally, reports must be submitted to specific committees if a federal facility is temporarily relocated for more than six months. The head of a federal department or agency must submit reports to specific committees if a federal facility is temporarily relocated for longer than 6 months. The reports include updates on the relocation status every 6 months. The head of a federal department or agency must submit reports to specific committees if a federal facility is temporarily relocated for longer than 6 months, with updates on the relocation status every 6 months thereafter. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. (a) Gulf Hurricane Disaster-Affected Small Business Concern defined as small businesses in Gulf hurricane-affected areas as of August 28, 2005.
(b) Gulf Hurricane Disaster defined as events caused by Hurricane Katrina or Rita declared major disasters by the President.
(c) Gulf Hurricane Disaster-Affected Area defined for the Act's purposes. For the purposes of this Act, a "Gulf hurricane disaster-affected area" refers to a county or parish in Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, or Texas designated for disaster assistance due to Hurricane Katrina or Rita. The term "small business concern" is defined as per its meaning under the Act. The term "small business concern" is defined under the Small Business Act for disaster assistance related to Hurricane Katrina or Rita. The Act will become effective 10 days after its enactment.
